content.description:
If developers in Canada were worried everyone south of the permafrost line would think they were soft as reeses pb cups sitting on your dashboard in the dead heat of summer, this route was graded with one purpose: to prove everyone wholly wrong. Start the route with some desperate lunges to sharp crimps. You didn't think this would be that enjoyable, eh? After an ok shake at some flat edges, launch into the lurping crux move off heinously bad but somehow sharp edges. From here, just one more long deadpoint (dyno for the short) and some techy half pad two finger pockets separate you from thy salvation. Now you are a 7c climber. Walk into the start of the 'pavement' section of the upper wall (far right). See the rf dihedral slappiness of Army Ants at about the 3rd bolt? A few routes to the right is you. If you see a hold that you'd have to jump to off the ground awkwardly, that's 'Jump you prick, Jump!' and you are one route too far right.

Usually a stack of rocks to allow shorties to reach the starting holds. All bolts. Stick clip the first (and probably the second) for sure.

This excellent route starts just left of a leaning tree (by climbing in from Rockemoveya then traversing right on a few pockets). A powerful mid pitch boulder problem is followed by a slab Crux at the top.

Pavement
bolts

A really hard boulder problem separates you from the jugs and fun up top. Flag super hard with the left foot if you can't use the sloper outright. Sometimes done as a warm up by skipping the bolder crux at the third bolt. 

Bolts

To the Left of the cave. Basically starts in the steeps and goes to Alitus. 

Left Cave route
10 bolts or so

Classic for the grade. This power enduro test piece weaves up the beauty streak. Bouldery!

right where the pavement meets the cave
bolts

Bouldering on a rope. 

Between Leviathan and Shine
Bolts (usually fixed)

Climb the grey corner on miniature holds.

right side
bolts

This was definately Canada's hardest route in 2006. Many have climbed on it and many have traveled to see it. Probably one of those test pieces people will talk about once Ace becomes a bit more popular with the international crowd. I don't think Megos onsighted this one, and I heard that it took Graham about 6 days. Regardless, very hard. 

I heard somewhere the name comes from "ass out" or that your butt is pushed in a way that it makes you look strange. If that's what it takes to send thing thing then count me in. 

The top is 13+ slab bouldering so don't think the crux is the end of it. 

The king line in the cave. Connects with kinder surprise. 
Bolts

You better have fingers of steel and ligaments of concrete. A hard sewries of pulls off the ground leads to easier crimps- a nice rest and a very reachy crux. Easier above.

right side
bolts

A viciously crimpy and technical crux at the second bolt stops must suitors in their tracks. If you survive this section, easier climbing with plenty of rests leads to a heartbreaking finish.


far right of pavement
bolts

I don't know much about this route. I think it's two really big moves and a hard anchor clip. Otherwise, I don't think I've ever seen anyone do it. Probably a good route!

Bolts

So you climbed The Warm-Up, but were left unsatiated. Have no fear, Dale's Extender is a fantastic 2 more moves on buckets passing one more bolt to a higher set of anchors. It even gets you a bonus grade, because you likely came to Ace to hunt 5.11b. 



Extension of "The Warm-Up"

permas

From Ondra's Facebook account:

"Disbelief" 5.15b (9b), probably upper end of the grade. Acephale, Canmore, Canada.
It was a crazy day. I almost wanted to give up. After two tries, when I got to the crux move (which is actually a foot move) totally fresh, I would slip off for like 15th time. No light at the end of the tunnel...despite the fact I stuck the move 10 days ago once, only to fall off 2 moves higher. On my 3rd try of the day, I somehow did not slip and did not fall. I cannot think many other routes where I climbed so close to my limit." -Ondra 

The Blank Slab right of Army Ants. Direct Start to unknown stuntman. 
bolts

Short cruxes separated by good rests lead to sustained climbing, a stout deadpoint move and a dicey edit onto the upper slab. A final tough move below the anchor keeps things interesting.

pavement
bolts

This is the big boy route for all the weekend warriors out there. Athletic, bouldery, long-but-not-too-long and through the cave, proper. Nothing really is quite like Endless Summer. 

Unlike some of the neighboring climbs, this one is still in the realm of possibility for most strong boulderers. Many battle with this fierce climb. Most of it is done after the very obvious lip crux but many fall after this due to pump or missing the key holds.

Be warned, however, as there can be a very long line on this project for that very reason.  

Next to existance mundane and Bunda 
bolts

Everyone who's done this one has said that the heel hooking on this is wild and out of control. A few strong guys have admitted to having it change them, and not for the better. Be warned, this thing is hard and not friendly.

Sonnie Trotter infamously removed the last glued edge on this thing. Not sure if it made it harder but surely not easier. 

Next to Endless and Prime Time
Bolts

Many intricate cruxes stand between you and the anchors including one at ground level. Start in a mailbox slot just left of the first bolt.

paveement
bolts

After the double gaston iron cross of prime time, move right into what seems like a blank wall. Very hard. 

What is usually associated as the last of the cave routes at the Upper Wall on the leftmost side. 
bolts

Popular linkup. After both cruxes of Army Ants, traverse left on good holds to finish on upper cruxes of First Flight.

Start on Army Ants
bolts

Stick clip the second bolt and boulder in from the right to gain the no hands rest ledge (have your belayer stay out from under your feet, lots of crumbly rock). Head straight up over the bulge to gain another no hands rest- this one is much more tenuous. 

From here, the real climbing starts. Using pockets/holes, slopers, and on rare occasion, a crimp, gain a solid cross legged knee-bar just below a final bulge. Get psyched and boulder over the bulge with one of 2 options (or more). 1) Up/Left; powerful undercling, horrible pockets, and an even worse sloper. 2) Right/Up; mediocre pinch, desperate thumb-press/footwork and a more desperate crimp match. With either method, clipping the last bolt is very strenuous, but skipping it is ill-advised; the route is definitely not over. 

Skip bolt 1, and long draw bolts 2/3 to minimize rope drag. 



From Upper Ace proper, head down the approach trail and split right, up onto the ledge. Walk to the end (climbers left) of the ledge where there is a rope between two bolts to aid "Swelltone Theatre". This is the first bolt line to the right, it starts in the back of the cave and pulls through the weakness just right of the first no-hands ledge. Start from the cheater stone pile to the right. 

9(?) bolts, 2 bolt anchor with biners

An Alex Megos FA that has yet so see a second ascent. Originally bolted by Evan Hau.

Can't say I know much about it as it just looks hard. Feel free to comment about it if you've tried it.

Half nelson (half way) give you 13a.

Bolts

People seem to like this but due to the nature of both pitches (bottom of Fully Gingus is called just Jingus Americanus), they are usually considered two climbs, both worthy in their own right. 

More climbing after the tough anchor clip gives you a whole new letter grade!

Extention of Gingus. 
Bolts

Sometimes spelled "Jingus," this route is hard right from the start. Eases up quite a bit until the anchor (very hard to clip). Fully Gingus / Jingus is the extension.

Not sure what the correct spelling is however. 

Next to whale back. 
bolts

A link up that starts on The Hood and ends on Altius. Seldom tried. 

Bolts

The most climbed on 13b / 8a in the valley? People like it because it's never wet and always fun. Others hate it because it's usually pretty busy and not super sustained. 

bolts

Some obvious chipping on this route makes it a bit less interesting than others but worthwhile nonetheless. Hard finish with mostly small holds.

bolts

A v6 boulder problem at the 2nd bolt gives way to easy climbing then a 12b/c move over a bulge. Soft for grade if you boulder enough.

pavement
bolts

love it or hate it, a v7/v8 lurks at the 2nd bolt into a fun 12a above. hmmmm

pavement
bolts

From Josh's Sendage quote:

"Really insecure heel hook iron cross into a low percent out of control dyno. This route might be easy for someone tall, I'm not sure. I suggested 9a because it felt that hard to me compared to other routes in the area but it may only be due to the insecure nature of the route. Time will tell."

Next to kinder surprise and connects into Bunda
Bolts

Start to the right of the big tree. Boulder up to some hidden holds over a small roof before causing baby blue stone to the anchor.

pavement
bolts

Stick clip the high first bolt and start from the left. Trend left up the weakness at the first bolt climbing past 2 bolts on the way to a rest on a shelf. Forget about the awkwardness you have just experienced and try to recover, the real climb starts here!

Follow the left bolt line on good holds (skin friendly pockets and buckets) to a high undercling rest. Boulder out of the rest using whatever strategy suits your height and pull the bulge for a couple last moves to the chains. Don't blow it on the final crimps and side pulls!



From Upper Ace proper, head down the approach trail and split right, up onto the ledge. Look for the shallow overhanging corner with a left slanting weakness. The boulder at the base is covered in white, it's not chalk. The route name is faintly written in chalk

13 bolts, drop in anchor

Start as for Le Bleu du Ciel by stick clipping the high first bolt climbing just left of the plumb line. Trend left up the weakness at the first bolt climbing past 2 bolts on the way to a rest on a shelf. Here, the lines diverge - cross on the bucket and traverse right to clip the 4th bolt, then head up (and a bit more right).

Slam through buckets and good pockets to a high knee bar rest with a side pull jug about the size of a kitchen sink. Gain back whatever you have lost and boulder up and left through a mysteriously blank section of wall. Race the pump over the bulge with a strenuous final bolt before pulling onto the slab to stand up and clip the chains. 



From Upper Ace proper, head down the approach trail and split right, up onto the ledge. Look for the shallow overhanging corner with a left slanting weakness. The boulder at the base is covered in white, it's not chalk. This line splits right off of Le Bleu du Ciel after the 3rd bolt. 

10 bolts, drop in anchor

Boulder power combined with Power endurance, has a tough finish. Feels longer than it looks. Some holds are quite sharp as well. Bolted by Lev. 

Between Angst and Beam me up. 
8 bolts (fixed usually)

14a slab. Looks great!!! even has a slab dyno

pavement
bolts

Similar to other routes in the cave but has a notable double gaston and a very crimpy crux. The top is not that hard in comparison to other routes in this area and so not much separates you from the chains once you climb through the bottom. 

Next to first flight and existence 
Bolts

From the Boner anchor traverse right to some desperate undercling moves. A v6 boulder

above boner
bolts

This line features a hard boulder problem start and finish with technical climbing inbetween.

pavement right
bolts

Another bouldery problem through the main roof. 

Between beam me up and kinder surprise 
Bolts

This is an excellent line at the Upper Wall. 
  
 It is very characteristic of the climbing in the center of the Upper Wall. Sapping blocky enduro leads straight into the slopey, power-draining blue-grey goodness. 
  
 Be prepared to pull out all the stops at both cruxes, with a lousy half-shake in between. They require the employment of differing methods, with long slaps to slopers at the first, and desperate (or are they??) stabs to crimps at the second.

Located to the right of the warmup. This route starts with a pull onto a bit of a hanging wall and a shallow lf dihedral, then goes through a few bulges.
All bolts

Two starts:

1: Fixed rope debauchery from the ledge (tie in and huck your rope down, make sure your belayer is clear of rockfall from the ledge)

2: Full value corner from the bottom (climb up a couple of bolts to the ledge and then probably end up using the fixed rope anyway)

From the ledge, use the left bolt line and extend (at least double length) the draws which protect gaining the next ledge. Pull the mini-boulder onto the ledge and clip the mega length draw. Weave up through easy terrain to your next bolt, here the climb finally starts. 

Pull big a big move, crossing a slight bulge to gain the right facing corner. Follow pockets and tufa-like features to gain the high tufa. Boulder through the next bulge and exit slightly right on good crimps pulling one final move to gain the lip. Turn the lip and clip the chains, don't be afraid to grab the chains if someone locked the biner...



From Upper Wall proper, head down the path cutting right onto the lower of the two ledges. Look for the fixed rope, this bolt line can be reached from the fixed rope. 

10 bolts, chains w a locking biner

Climb the intro moves of Army ants, then bust right for a traversing crux on small holds. Easier climbing in the middle leads to a wild upper crux.

Starts on Army Ants
bolts

An OK warm up. Link into Bataille (via. Dale's Extender) for a nice 11c

bolts

Hard pockets, slopey jugs, and a weird mantle move (the whale's back) at the top of it all. A great climb at the grade and probably just as hard as sweet thing (seem to be the consensus between all the climbers).

Right of sweet thing. 
Bolts

Maybe the best "hard hard" area in Canada? A very good collection of 5.14s, 5.13s and a beautiful wall. If you climb this grade you already know about this beauty. Visited and bolted by such names as Lev Pinter, Josh Muller, Joe Kinder, Dave Graham, Sonnie Trotter, Alex Megos, Adam Ondra, Jonathan Siegrist and many more. The icebox is the place to be!
